body:
First thing: The original didn't have tests. I did run all rails test, but you are right, so tests will be added.

Second thing: Database lock - Users of Activerecord session-store are probably are using Mysql - INNODB, which uses row-level locking. For example: our app has a dashboard page, which uses ajax for the content of a couple of widgets. With the current rails session store implementation each ajax request is causing an UPDATE on the sessions table. Because Innodb is locking the sessiondata-row when writing on update, all ajax requests are executed in sequence instead of parallel. This will be true for any database that does lock-on-write.

It's correct that this is changing the behavior of updated_at from last accessed to last changed, but the current behavior of db-sessionstore is making it unusable for parallel ajax-heavy applications.

Third thing: Are you sure? Because I can't think of a situation when just comparing marshalled data will cause a problem. Comparing the unmarshalled data if the marshalled data is different would be an additional optimization which will probably create more overhead that just updating the session.
